title: Trini Doubles (Channa & Bara)
description: Trini Doubles are a beloved street food from Trinidad and Tobago featuring spiced curried chickpeas (channa) tucked between two soft, fried flatbreads called bara. Bright with cilantro, mango chutney-like tamarind chutney, and a warming blend of Caribbean spices, they deliver savory, tangy, and mildly spicy layers in every handheld bite.

ingredients.notes: soaked overnight if using dried; or use two 15-oz cans (drained) as equivalent

ingredients.display_name: vegetable oil (for frying bara) plus oil for cooking
ingredients.notes: approx. 2 1/2 cups; enough for shallow frying and sautéing

ingredients.display_name: warm water (for bara dough and soaking chickpeas if dried)
ingredients.notes: about 1 1/2 cups; additional water if needed for dough or soaking
about 2 tsp total, divided between dough and channa
about 1/2 tsp, optional for deeper flavor

ingredients.display_name: fresh green chili or scotch bonnet, minced (adjust to taste)
ingredients.notes: use milder chili or omit for lower heat
about 4-5 stalks, used in bara dough and garnish
about 2 tbsp; can substitute mango chutney if preferred
about 1 1/2 tsp to help bara puff

ingredients.display_name: cooked chickpea cooking liquid (aquafaba) or water
ingredients.notes: use to adjust bara dough consistency if needed

ingredients.display_name: salted mango or vegetable pickle / pepper sauce (optional for serving)

steps.text: If using dried chickpeas, soak them in plenty of cold water overnight (8-12 hours). If using canned chickpeas, drain and rinse and skip soaking.

Cook chickpeas: drain soaked chickpeas, place in a pot, cover with fresh water, add a bay leaf and a pinch of salt, bring to a simmer and cook until tender (about 45-60 minutes). If using a pressure cooker or instant pot, cook under pressure for 20-25 minutes. Reserve some cooking liquid and drain remaining for channa.

Prepare bara dough: in a bowl combine flour, baking powder, instant yeast, sugar and salt. Stir in finely sliced scallions, then add warm water gradually and a splash of aquafaba or water until a soft sticky dough forms. Knead briefly to bring together but keep slightly tacky. Cover and let rest/prove in a warm spot for 30 minutes to 45 minutes until slightly puffy.

While dough is resting, prepare channa base: heat a couple of tablespoons oil in a skillet over medium heat, add finely chopped onion and sauté until translucent (about 4-5 minutes). Add minced garlic and minced chili and cook briefly until fragrant.

Add spices to the aromatics: stir in turmeric, ground cumin, ground coriander, and optional garam masala and cook 1 minute to bloom the spices. Add the cooked chickpeas and a splash of reserved cooking liquid or water, gently simmer and mash a few chickpeas for a saucy texture. Season with salt and pepper and simmer until thickened, about 8-10 minutes. Finish with lime juice and chopped cilantro.

Make tamarind chutney (optional): combine tamarind paste with brown sugar and a little water in a small saucepan, simmer gently until slightly thickened and balanced between sweet and tart, then cool.

Shape and fry bara: divide rested dough into 12 equal pieces for 6 servings (two per serving). Flatten each piece into a thin disc about 10-12 cm across. Heat oil in a wide skillet to medium-high (approx 175-190°C if using a thermometer). Fry discs one or two at a time until puffed and golden, about 1-2 minutes per side. Drain on paper towels.

Assemble doubles: place a warm bara on a plate, spoon a generous portion of channa onto the center, drizzle with tamarind chutney and optional pepper sauce, sprinkle chopped cilantro and sliced scallions. Top with a second bara or fold single bara over filling depending on preference.
Serve immediately while bara are warm and slightly crisp at edges. Leftover channa can be refrigerated and gently reheated; bara are best fresh but can be warmed briefly in a skillet.
